title: Ask HN: Do you write a lot of SDKs for your APIs?
text:
At work, I find myself writing a Python/Go/JS SDK for every single internal API that I implement. This might even be more prevalent for public facing APIs since creating/maintaining public API SDKs for popular languages are table stakes for usage.

- Has this generally been true in your experience as well?

- If so, are there any hacks to create these SDKs with support for best practices like pagination, retry, etc + update them them when the API changes?

Ask HN: What are your goto songs which you listen for specific emotional states?
text:
Hi all Over the years , I have a collection of songs for many of my emotional/mental states for e.g

Stressful situations like Loved one in an emergency or even prior to a Tech interview https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_HpzT62txo [Buddhist Meditation]

Nostalgia about the days gone by https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XXsjbv47Amk [Sundial Dream , Kevin Kern]

In the zone music [mostly at the time of coding or email tagging/filtering :-)] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5SfJg_fp3A&t=4006s [Cafe del mar , Lounge music]

Gym/Running/Pumped Up https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WU7SGn0MeP0 [Epic Music]

Peaceful https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Tr0otuiQuU [Beethoven, Moonlight Sonata] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NlprozGcs80 [Pachelbel , Canon in D Major]

Would love to hear your go to songs and situations.

Ask HN: Is it time for software engineering to be a licensed job?
text:
In our society, any job or task in which you can be a serious threat to a person requires first obtaining a license that is easily revoked if you ever engage in shady practices. Doctors, teachers, lawyers, electricians, and even driving are notorious examples.

Most software engineers don't work in projects that could be considered dangerous to society when misused, but those who work at global tech like Meta and Google easily fall into this box.

Given how often these companies show complete disregard to society and how more powerful they're getting with every passing day, is it time to regulate the field of software engineering?

Ask HN: How to network with executives as an MBA student?
text:
I'll soon be attending events with higher-ups of companies I'm interested in working for. While I certainly don't place people on pedestals, I don't want to make a fool of myself either.

How should an MBA student go about conversing with executive of major companies? What are the non-obvious questions and etiquette I should keep in mind?

My professors have given us preparation and tips, but I'm also curious what some of the HN folks have to say.

Ask HN: How do you ensure that a distributed app is working as expected?
text:
Imagine a very simple user creation flow in an online marketplace:

- Service A (user service) receives the request and creates a user object and sends an async request to service B and C (e.g. via Kafka)

- Service B (notification service) receives the request and sends an email to the newly created user

- Service C (referral service) receives the request and credits some funds to the referrer

While this design might be laid out correctly in a design doc, it is only implicitly defined in code because the services talk to each other. How would you:

- Ensure that the services are talking to each other in the correct order when implementing the user creation flow (integration tests might not suffice here since they generally test a very narrow set of path)?

- Define and enforce SLO guarantees between services in production?

- Debug which service is to blame when the flow breaks down?

Ask HN: To store display results in a search index or not to
text:
We are designing our talent database search experience (think LinkedIn people search).

The search is driven by an Algolia-like service.

At the moment, we storing both the attributes that are used to search and the attributes that are used to display data. Most of the time, they are the same.

This design is great because it made the initial rollout simple.

However, there are a few problems that we already identified:

* There is no way to display sensitive data without an additional roundtrip to the server. We cannot store it in the search index, and if we are doing the roundtrip anyway, then it defeats the argument that this way is faster. * The entire index needs to be resynced every time a new attribute is added to the display dataset. * Engineers need to know how to update index data in addition to knowing how to API. * Potential for stale data in cards when queue times are long

These are a few arguments that make me want to switch to a different design, where we only store attributes used for search, and the only result we return is the search position and ID of the user, which is then used to fetch data about individual search results from the API.

I cannot see many downsides to the new approach, short of the additional roundtrip.

Is there anything else I should consider?
